body_html:
This happens with in-place operations as well:

a = torch.zeros(5) - 1
b = torch.LongTensor([1,2,3])

a[b].abs_()
# a is still [-1, -1, -1, -1, -1]

a[1:4].abs_() 
# a is now [-1, 1, 1, 1, -1]

It looks like advanced indexing returns a copy of the indexed tensor entries unless you assign values.
body_text:
This happens with in-place operations as well:
a = torch.zeros(5) - 1
b = torch.LongTensor([1,2,3])

a[b].abs_()
# a is still [-1, -1, -1, -1, -1]

a[1:4].abs_() 
# a is now [-1, 1, 1, 1, -1]

It looks like advanced indexing returns a copy of the indexed tensor entries unless you assign values.
body:
This happens with in-place operations as well:

```
a = torch.zeros(5) - 1
b = torch.LongTensor([1,2,3])

a[b].abs_()
# a is still [-1, -1, -1, -1, -1]

a[1:4].abs_() 
# a is now [-1, 1, 1, 1, -1]
```

It looks like advanced indexing returns a copy of the indexed tensor entries unless you assign values.
